contents.title: Building with Windsurf - A Software Engineer's AI Journey
contents.description: Exploring agentic AI development with Windsurf - from static site to dynamic blog, with insights and learnings along the way.
contents.author: Manuel Waltschek

children.value: As an experienced web developer, I recently embarked on a journey with Windsurf, an agentic AI assistant, to transform my PDF CV into a modern website. This is the story of how we went from a basic static page to a fully deployed Vue.js application, and what I learned along the way.
Phase 1: From CV to First Static Site
The journey began with a simple PDF CV and a vision for a professional website. Here's how Windsurf helped bootstrap the project:
: I have my CV in PDF format. Can you help create a website that matches its style?
: I notice your CV uses #2962B3 as the primary color. Let's start with a basic HTML structure that maintains your brand identity:

props.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>Manuel Waltschek - Software Engineer</title>
  <style>
    :root { --primary: #2962B3; }
    body { font-family: system-ui, sans-serif; }
    .header { color: var(--primary); }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Basic content structure from CV -->
</body>
</html>

children.value: While functional, this initial static site lacked modern features and maintainability. We needed a more robust solution that could handle blog content and future scalability.
Coming from an Angular background, I wanted a framework that would offer similar component organization and type safety:
: The static site works, but I want to add a blog and make it more maintainable. What would you recommend?
: Given your Angular experience, I'd suggest Vue.js with Nuxt.js. Here's why:
TypeScript support out of the box
This aligned perfectly with my preference for clean code organization and type safety.
With the stack decided, we began the transformation process:

props.code:
# Initial project setup
npx nuxi init personal-website
cd personal-website

# Essential dependencies
npm install @nuxt/content @nuxtjs/tailwindcss
npm install --save-dev typescript @nuxt/types

children.value: We immediately hit our first technical challenge:
: Getting a TypeScript error about missing types
: Let's fix that by updating tsconfig.json:
The blog implementation revealed Windsurf's ability to handle complex features while maintaining clean code organization.
We started with the content structure:

props.code:
content/
  blog/
    welcome-to-my-blog.md
    building-with-windsurf.md
  cv/
    experience.md
    skills.md

children.value: Then came the markdown rendering challenges:
: The code blocks aren't rendering properly, and the syntax highlighting is missing
: We'll update the Nuxt Content configuration:
After fixing the content rendering, we tackled the blog layout:
Working with Windsurf: A Practical Assessment
One of the most interesting aspects was how Windsurf adapted to my Angular-style component organization. Here's how we structured the hero section:
: I want the hero section to be a separate component with clean separation of template, script, and styles.
: Perfect, let's create a modular hero component with animations. Here's the structure:
This component structure follows familiar Angular patterns, maintaining the clean separation of concerns I value while leveraging Vue's modern features.
With components in place, we focused on consistent styling. A key challenge was the blog typography:
: The blog post headings need work. Can we make them match the CV's style?
: Let's use your brand color and create a clean hierarchy:
This maintained visual consistency with my CV while providing clear content hierarchy.
To streamline the development process, we set up proper tooling:
First, a Makefile for common tasks:

props.code:
# Makefile
.PHONY: dev build preview deploy

dev:        ## Start development server
    npm run dev

build:      ## Build for production
    npm run build

preview:    ## Preview production build
    npm run preview

deploy: build   ## Deploy to GitHub Pages
    @echo "Deploying to GitHub Pages..."

children.value: Next, GitHub Actions for continuous deployment:

props.code:
# .github/workflows/deploy.yml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '16'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build
      - name: Deploy
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./dist

children.value: Throughout development, we tackled several key challenges:
Challenge: Maintaining Angular-like structure in Vue
Solution: Clear separation of template, script, and styles
Solution: Proper type declarations and strict mode
Solution: Configured Nuxt SSG and base URL

props.code:
# Personal Website

Modern personal website built with Vue.js/Nuxt.js, featuring:
- Component-based architecture
- TypeScript integration
- Markdown blog with syntax highlighting
- Automated GitHub Pages deployment

## Development

\`\`\`bash
# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start development server
make dev

# Build and preview
make build
make preview

contents.title: Welcome to My Journey with AI and Software Development
contents.description: Exploring the intersection of Spring Framework, AI technologies, and modern software development practices.
contents.author: Manuel Waltschek

children.value: As a software engineer passionate about AI technologies and robust backend development, I'm excited to share my journey exploring the future of software development. This blog will document my experiences with emerging AI tools and frameworks, while sharing insights about building scalable web services.
This blog focuses on practical applications of AI in software development, best practices in backend development, and the evolution of developer tools and productivity.
Agentic AI, Spring AI, LLMs, RAGs, Embeddings
Spring Framework, APIs, Web Services, Clean Code

While there are many tech blogs out there, I believe my combination of Spring Framework expertise and enthusiasm for AI technologies offers a unique perspective on where software development is heading.
My expertise and interests center around:
Spring Framework and enterprise Java development
Through this blog, I aim to share:
Practical experiences with AI development tools
Insights into building robust web services
Real-world applications of emerging AI technologies
Journey of creating AI-powered developer tools
Stay tuned as I explore the exciting intersection of AI and software development, with a particular focus on Spring AI and tools for enhancing developer productivity!
